author: By Marie Fazio
title: Rapper Arrested After Bragging About Unemployment Fraud in Video
description: Fontrell Antonio Baines, who performs as Nuke Bizzle, illegally obtained $1.2 million in jobless benefits intended for workers idled by the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities said.
content: A rapper who boasted in a music video about getting rich by fraudulently applying for unemployment has been accused of using stolen identities to obtain more than $1.2 million in jobless benefits, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Post Published Hunter Biden Report Amid Newsroom Doubts
description: Some reporters withheld their bylines and questioned the credibility of an article that made the tabloid’s front page on Wednesday.
content: The New York Post’s front-page article about Hunter Biden on Wednesday was written mostly by a staff reporter who refused to put his name on it, two Post employees said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Von Ehren and Andrew Dore
title: Play a Halloween Pencil Game, if You Dare
description: Finding the sinister words will reveal the spooky images that go along with them.
content: There are 19 Halloween-themed words or phrases waiting for you in the grid here. Drawing lines to connect the letters will reveal 10 hidden images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bianca Giaever and Desiree Ibekwe
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Jim Dwyer, About New York’
description: A farewell to the late Pulitzer Prize-winning Times journalist.
content: Jim Dwyer, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist for The New York Times, died earlier this month. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Quickly Realized I Now Had to Pedal For the Weight of Two Men’
description: A beer delivery in Brooklyn, an emergency saxophone repair and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Infections in U.S. and Europe Show Troubling Trend
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 18, 2020.
content: “In the spring, it was fear and a sense of, ‘We are all in it together.’ Things are different now. Fear has really been replaced with fatigue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for $550,000, or Less
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Remote but Inclusive for Years, and Now Showing Other Companies How
description: Ultranauts has been developing creative ways to hire, manage and motivate a far-flung and diverse work force for seven years.
content: From her home in Beaverton, Ore., Jamie Davila leads a team of eight engineers in seven states for the technology start-up Ultranauts. Like millions of other people during these work-from-home times, she relies on popular communication tools like Zoom and Slack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What’s in a Neighborhood Name? Marketing, Mostly
description: What’s more New York than slapping a name on a collection of streets? One Manhattan area has the rare chance to christen its own neighborhood.
content: Q: I’ve lived on 24th Street and Second Avenue for 50 years, and the neighborhood’s name seems to be changing. It has generally been called Gramercy Park, and at one point there was talk about naming the area Rose Hill. But recently I’ve seen it referred to as Kips Bay, which I thought started in the high 20s. I’d love to know if there is an official name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Bruce Springsteen Is Living in the Moment
description: “Letter to You,” his new album with the E Street Band, is built on lessons and skills accumulated in the past. But the Boss is focused on where he stands now — and where he’s going next.
content: Every music fan with blood burning in their veins has felt the sting of missing live shows since March, but the pain has been particularly acute for Bruce Springsteen, an artist who’s spent the past six decades onstage, yet says he’s just now hitting his stride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Biden Says He Gets Places Like Scranton. Some in Town Aren’t So Sure.
description: Scranton, Pa., is no longer the dying coal town of Joseph Biden’s youth. It is more racially diverse and prosperous, and not everyone there is enthusiastic about his candidacy.
content: SCRANTON, Pa. — Despite it all, Gabriel Perez, the Empanada King of Scranton, is still hopeful about America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: What the N.B.A.’s East Teams Need: Playmakers and Trade Partners
description: Some teams are one move away from contention. Others, not so much. Here are our suggestions for how each team can improve.
content: The N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference is more open than ever, coming off a season in which an upstart fifth seed made it to the finals. At least one team is virtually guaranteed to vault into the top tier from mediocrity: the Nets, given that Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving are expected to return from injury for the 2020-21 season. But otherwise, it should be a slugfest from start to finish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Rays Stick to Their Plan and Reach a 2nd World Series
description: Guided by the club’s strict principles, Manager Kevin Cash pulled his pitcher at a crucial point in Game 7 and was rewarded with a victory over the Houston Astros.
content: The Tampa Bay Rays told Charlie Morton it would happen. When they chased him as a free agent before last season, their front office did not present to him this precise scenario — an unprecedented path to the World Series, with him leading the way — but they shared their methodology. Part of Morton recoiled at the message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: How to Have a Safe and Still Spooky Halloween
description: Scavenger hunts, outdoor movie screenings and other ideas to have a safe holiday on Oct. 31.
content: In some ways, 2020 would make for the perfect Halloween: the holiday falls on a Saturday, and it’s a full moon (specifically, a “blue moon,” an event that occurs only once every couple of years).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Jack Nicas
title: As Local News Dies, a Pay-for-Play Network Rises in Its Place
description: A nationwide operation of 1,300 local sites publishes coverage that is ordered up by Republican groups and corporate P.R. firms.
content: The instructions were clear: Write an article calling out Sara Gideon, a Democrat running for a hotly contested U.S. Senate seat in Maine, as a hypocrite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: New York shuts down a wedding amid fears it would draw 10,000 people.
description: A wedding with up 10,000 guests? In Brooklyn, near a coronavirus hot spot?
content: A wedding with up 10,000 guests? In Brooklyn, near a coronavirus hot spot?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: The Conners Return to Confront the Coronavirus
description: This ABC sitcom has dealt with real-world challenges since its earliest days as “Roseanne.” In its new season, those include the pandemic and its fallout.
content: When “The Conners” returned to set in mid-August after a lengthy pandemic delay, John Goodman had no doubt that every safety precaution had been taken. But his heart still fluttered a bit when it came time to finally get to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lina Zeldovich
title: Some Signs of Recovery From Severe Covid Lung Damage
description: In two early studies, researchers said some patients showed signs of healing just weeks after leaving the hospital.
content: When Annie Coissieux tried to stand up for the first time after weeks in the hospital battling Covid-19, she couldn’t get on her feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Paleontologists See Stars as Software Bleeps Scientific Terms
description: When their annual conference was moved online, they were amused to find seemingly benign words blocked and replaced with asterisks during virtual sessions.
content: The trouble started when Thomas R. Holtz Jr., an expert on the Tyrannosaurus rex, typed “Hell Creek Formation,” the rock unit in Montana where the remains of North America’s last giant dinosaurs have been found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Facebook Cracks Down
description: Jobs are disappearing again, and stimulus talks look deader than ever.
content: Happy Sunday, and hope you’re staying safe and healthy. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns
title: Trump Runs the Kind of Campaign He Likes, but Not the One He Might Need
description: With little time left to change the trajectory of the race, there is a large gulf separating the president’s experience of the campaign from the more sobering assessments of party officials.
content: In public, President Trump and his campaign team project a sense of optimism and bravado. When they meet with Republican donors and state party leaders, presidential aides insist they are fully capable of achieving a close victory over Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Nov. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: Get the Birds To Come To You
description: Backyard birding has become the perfect pandemic pastime. Here’s how to draw more species to your yard, and maybe get a good photo, too.
content: Hosting a gathering of friends at your home may not be advisable at this time, but getting together with a flock of feathered friends is a great diversion. During the pandemic, birding has become a popular escape with sales for seed suppliers, birdhouse builders and other bird related businesses “through the roof,” according to Audubon Magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Thomas Kaplan
title: Would Biden’s Tax Plan Help or Hurt a Weak Economy?
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is pitching tax hikes on corporations and the rich. Many economists say they won’t hurt growth. Some conservative economists — and President Trump — say they’ll crush the recovery.
content: At a drive-in campaign rally last week at a union hall in Toledo, Ohio, Joseph R. Biden Jr. asked those in the audience to beep their car horns if they earned more than $400,000 a year. “You’re going to get a tax raise,” he declared as some cars honked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Najim Rahim and Fatima Faizi
title: A Storied Female Warlord Surrenders, Taliban Say, Exposing Afghan Weakness
description: She was undefeated in decades of war, but her decision was an act of survival. A government that has come to depend on unreliable militias finds itself vulnerable.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a long conflict waged by men, she’s been a rare female warlord, defending her fief in northern Afghanistan against the Taliban, her own relatives and even against the American-backed central government she allied with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: China Threatens to Detain Americans if U.S. Prosecutes Chinese Scholars
description: American officials said China had insisted that the Justice Department not proceed with cases against the arrested scholars, who are in the Chinese military and face charges of visa fraud.
content: WASHINGTON — Chinese officials have told the Trump administration that security officers in China might detain American citizens if the Justice Department proceeds with prosecutions of arrested scholars who are members of the Chinese military, American officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: ‘We Have to Speak Out’: Thai Students Defy Protest Ban
description: Armed with umbrellas, social media and global support, young Thais are taking on a government that has used arrests, legal intimidation and water cannons to try to stop them.
content: BANGKOK — Thai authorities shut down parts of Bangkok’s commercial center and crippled public rail networks over the weekend in an effort to prevent young demonstrators from continuing their antigovernment protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: ‘It’s insane’: This is what happened when schools reopened in a virus-hit community.
description: In mid-September, parents of students at Corner Canyon High School, in an affluent suburb of Salt Lake City, received a text urging them to beg the school board to keep classrooms open.
content: In mid-September, parents of students at Corner Canyon High School, in an affluent suburb of Salt Lake City, received a text urging them to beg the school board to keep classrooms open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: In Election, Bolivia Confronts Legacy of Ousted Socialist Leader
description: Sunday’s election is seen as a referendum on Evo Morales, who lifted many out of poverty in his 14 years as president, but whose policies and tone divided the country.
content: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Adalid Zelada fully supported Evo Morales when Bolivia chose him as the country’s first Indigenous president in 2005.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: N.Y. Shuts Down Hasidic Wedding That Could Have Had 10,000 Guests
description: The ultra-Orthodox synagogue in Brooklyn accused state officials of “unwarranted attacks” on the wedding.
content: New York State health officials have taken extraordinary steps to shut down an ultra-Orthodox wedding planned for Monday that could have had brought up to 10,000 guests to Brooklyn, near one of New York City’s coronavirus hot spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: What Bryan Washington Is Cooking
description: His literary interests include Houston, Osaka, food and the transitory periods in personal relationships. In his debut novel, “Memorial,” he documents all four.
content: When describing his new book, “Memorial,” Bryan Washington has called it a gay slacker dramedy, a lowercase love story and a novel about the creases in relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Bess Abell, Social Secretary in Johnson White House, Dies at 87
description: Averting last-minute crises is part of the job description; she was built for it, carried it out in style and had a good time doing it.
content: Bess Abell, the White House social secretary during President Lyndon B. Johnson’s administration, was code-named “Iron Butterfly.” She had a light touch and exuded charm and warmth, but she was organized, efficient and tough as nails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Sergey Ponomarev
title: At Front Lines of a Brutal War: Death and Despair in Nagorno-Karabakh
description: Times journalists find civilians huddling in basements as a three-week-old conflict over the disputed Caucasus territory hints of a long and punishing fight.
content: STEPANAKERT, Nagorno-Karabakh — On the front line, the stench is overwhelming. The remains of fighters have been lying there for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 18, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 18, 2020.
content: ​EDITORS’ NOTE
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Michael Levenson
title: Man Arrested After Threatening Wichita Mayor Over Face Masks, Police Say
description: Text messages from the man contained a “very descriptive plan of execution,” including locating the mayor, hanging him and turning him into fertilizer, Mayor Brandon Whipple said.
content: Mayor Brandon Whipple of Wichita, Kan., said he often gets “goofy” threats, like the time someone said they wanted to attack him with a Goodyear blimp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
title: Why These Voters Rejected Hillary Clinton but Are Backing Joe Biden
description: For many Democrats and independents who sat out 2016, voted for third-party candidates or backed Donald Trump, Mr. Biden is more acceptable to them in ways large and small than Mrs. Clinton was.
content: Samantha Kacmarik, a Latina college student in Las Vegas, said that four years ago, she had viewed Hillary Clinton as part of a corrupt political establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Using a Law It Hates, Far Right in Spain Takes Aim at Franco’s Rivals
description: Vox, an ultranationalist party in Madrid, is working to remove memorials to Socialist figures of the 1930s, calling the effort a warning that a “law of historical memory” should be abolished.
content: MADRID — Leftist politicians in Spain have worked slowly but steadily over the years to remove symbols commemorating the former dictator Gen. Francisco Franco from public spaces across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: The Chicago 7 Trial Onscreen: An Interpretation for Every Era
description: Aaron Sorkin is only the latest filmmaker to dramatize this prime example of political theater. Each version has a different understanding of the case and what it means.
content: Abbie Hoffman described the trial of the Chicago 7 as “a great show,” and for the past 50 years, moviemakers have agreed. Aaron Sorkin’s new Netflix production “The Trial of the Chicago 7” is the fourth filmed dramatization of the 1969 prosecution of Hoffman, Jerry Rubin, Tom Hayden, David Dellinger, Rennie Davis, Lee Weiner and John Froines, who faced federal charges of conspiracy and incitement of the riots at the 1968 Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: What to Watch in Sports Right Now
description: Sports rebounded from early closures amid the coronavirus pandemic. Though several league bubbles have popped, these tournaments and titles are yet to be taken.
content: The N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. titles were claimed, the N.H.L.’s Stanley Cup won and the French Open champions crowned — all in the last three weeks. But there’s still a lot for sports fans to look forward to. Here, some of the biggest events of the next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Petrow
title: Dating Means Fear. Again.
description: I never imagined I’d live to witness another viral threat.
content: Bob and I stood on his deck of his San Francisco flat, with the bright lights of the city behind us and the first wisps of the summer fog creeping in. The attraction was palpable. His finger traced the outline of my nose — and then we kissed. It was our first — romantic and passionate. And more: fraught with the unknown. The year was 1988, still early in the AIDS epidemic, when about one in two gay men in the city had been infected with H.I.V. We had not yet had the talk (“Do you know your status?”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Patriots Struggle to Find Their Way After Schedule Shuffle
description: For the first time since 2001, New England (2-3) has a losing record after five games. The team looked out of sorts in a game that had been postponed twice because of Covid-19.
content: Nineteen years ago, in what was Bill Belichick’s second season in New England and Tom Brady’s first year as an N.F.L. starter, the Patriots had a 2-3 record at the second week of October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 19, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Monika Pronczuk and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: After Fleeing Poland, an Antiracism Activist Finds Refuge in Norway
description: A decision to grant asylum on political grounds highlights growing concerns over democratic backsliding in Poland.
content: The antiracism activist fled on New Year’s Eve in 2018 with his wife and toddler, seeking refuge in Norway, which has long welcomed political refugees from desperate corners of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Takes on Trump and Biden’s Dueling Town Halls
description: “Saturday Night Live” also mocked NBC for its choice to schedule a town hall with President Trump opposite an ABC event featuring Joe Biden.
content: NBC’s news division came under fire this week for hosting a town hall event with President Trump on Thursday night that competed with a similar program that ABC had already scheduled with Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Sarah Mervosh and Marc Santora
title: Pandemic weariness is making it harder to stem outbreaks, health officials say.
description: In parts of the world where the coronavirus is resurging, the outbreaks and a rising sense of apathy are colliding, making for a dangerous combination.
content: In parts of the world where the coronavirus is resurging, the outbreaks and a rising sense of apathy are colliding, making for a dangerous combination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: ‘Out of Control’: When Schools Opened in a Virus Hot Spot
description: In a suburban Salt Lake City district, coronavirus cases spiked as students returned to their classrooms.
content: On a Friday in mid-September, Sunny Washington got a text from another mother at her daughter’s high school in an affluent suburb of Salt Lake City. Three weeks into the school year, the number of coronavirus cases at the school was rising, and the district was considering shifting to online instruction. The text urged parents to beg the school board to keep classrooms open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Liverpool’s Van Dijk Needs Surgery, a Cruel Twist in a Tough Year
description: Virgil van Dijk’s knee injury will dent his club’s Premier League title hopes. But it’s also a reminder that this season’s champions will be the teams that survive as much as excel.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — Virgil van Dijk walked gingerly around the side of the field, ruefully shaking his head, muttering under his breath. He stopped to offer Jürgen Klopp a grimace and then trudged on, out of Goodison Park. That will be the last Liverpool, and the Premier League, sees of the Dutchman for quite some time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Trump’s Sanctions on International Court May Do Little Beyond Alienating Allies
description: Critics say the administration has targeted a human rights lawyer with economic penalties meant for warlords, dictators and authoritarian governments.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo came to the State Department briefing room ready to punish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make a maqluba for your pod, or savor the leftovers of a comforting lentil and orzo stew.
content: Good morning. A few years ago, on assignment for The Times, Francis Lam went to Sunset Park, Brooklyn, to learn to make maqluba (above), a feat of Palestinian culinary engineering in which chicken and fried vegetables are cooked in deep layers of spiced rice and noodles, and then served maqluba, the Arabic word for upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic, Gina Kolata and Lucy Tompkins
title: As the Virus Surges, Stark Differences Over What Is Around the Corner
description: President Trump’s health secretary voiced optimism on Sunday that vaccines and treatments would soon save the day, but governors and experts issued bleak warnings about the public letting down its guard.
content: As the coronavirus continued to surge in many parts of the United States, officials and experts offered starkly different outlooks on Sunday about what was to come and when the situation might improve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: A top Palestinian official is in critical condition.
description: Saeb Erekat, a senior Palestinian official, was in critical condition on Monday after being hospitalized with the coronavirus.
content: Saeb Erekat, a senior Palestinian official, was in critical condition on Monday after being hospitalized with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Coronavirus Surge, 2020 Election, M.L.B. Playoffs: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Stephenson
title: How Mormons Fed Up With Trump Could Help Lift Biden in Arizona
description: Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints tend to vote Republican. But in Arizona, some find the president’s behavior at odds with their values and are shifting to Joe Biden.
content: TUCSON — For the better part of a century, members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints have made their political home under the Republican Party’s tent, motivated by conservative beliefs rooted in the family values, personal liberty and economic frugality of their faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Democrats Dare to Believe
description: Donald Trump himself doesn’t seem to think he stands a chance.
content: Democrats across the country are beginning to believe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Refugees Who Assisted the U.S. Military Find the Door to America Slammed Shut
description: President Trump has reduced the flow of refugees into the country to a trickle, and even Iraqis and Afghans who risked their lives for American service members have been cut off.
content: WASHINGTON — The certificate of appreciation that Hanadi Al Haidari’s family received for providing shelter, food and translation services for the United States military still looks brand-new, without even a crease. She keeps it next to her Iraqi passport in her new home in Denver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brennan and Rick Rojas
title: Colorado Wildfire Grows Into Largest in State History
description: Left vulnerable by dry conditions, more than 430,000 acres have burned so far in what has been one of the worst years ever for wildfires in the state.
content: BOULDER, Colo. — She was driving back to her home in the Colorado mountains on Saturday when she saw the ominous plume swirling into the sky. In an instant, Jyoti Sharp’s mind went back to 2013, the last time she had been forced out by nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: The Facebook-Twitter-Trump Wars Are Actually About Something Else
description: Our institutions have failed to rein in Donald Trump. So people look to Big Tech.
content: Much of the outrage around the Trump era and social media platforms — like, most recently, the decision by Facebook and Twitter to reduce the reach of a highly questionable New York Post story about Hunter Biden — is actually about government power and accountability. More specifically, people are angry about the absence of those things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: ‘Lock Them All Up’: Trump’s Whitmer Attack Fits a Damaging Pattern
description: Since returning to the campaign trail, the president has drawn only more attention to his difficulties with women and older voters by minimizing the pandemic and targeting female leaders.
content: As soon as President Trump was released from the hospital after being treated for the coronavirus, he and his allies began counting down the days until he could return to the campaign trail. By reviving his beloved rallies, they thought, he could both prove to voters that he was healthy enough to be re-elected and zero in on Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s vulnerabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Mysterious Autograph Hound’s Book Is Up for Auction
description: With Mary Todd Lincoln, Mark Twain and even Oscar Wilde, a mystery remains: How did Lafayette Cornwell get all these people to autograph his book?
content: The little book is a relic from the years after the Civil War, when autograph-crazy Americans collected signatures, a central building block of identity before fingerprinting, Social Security numbers or credit cards. A jeweler named Lafayette Cornwell collected more signatures than most people did — 400 or so, starting when he was a teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Prickly Plant
description: Fred Piscop returns to New York Times Crosswords after a long absence.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — A quick one today, but I will say that it is nice to see the constructor Fred Piscop back in the rotation, especially with such a smooth and entertaining Monday puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken and Alexandra Eaton
title: How Will the U.S. Combat Election Day Cyberwarfare? With Paper.
description: The 2016 U.S. election was a game changer for voting technology. Widespread Russian interference in our voting systems spurred new federal scrutiny of the country’s vast and fragmented election infrastructure. Four years later, “The psychological import of what the Russians did may be greater than anything that they actually hacked into, because they have managed to shake the confidence of American voters that their votes will be counted as they cast them,” said David Sanger, national security correspondent for The New York Times. And this lack of trust has led to a renewed examination of the nation’s voting equipment.
content: The 2016 U.S. election was a game changer for voting technology. Widespread Russian interference in our voting systems spurred new federal scrutiny of the country’s vast and fragmented election infrastructure. Four years later, “The psychological import of what the Russians did may be greater than anything that they actually hacked into, because they have managed to shake the confidence of American voters that their votes will be counted as they cast them,” said David Sanger, national security correspondent for The New York Times. And this lack of trust has led to a renewed examination of the nation’s voting equipment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Determined Thai protesters showed up despite transit blocks.
content: In the latest of months of demonstrations, tens of thousands of pro-democracy protesters gathered in Bangkok and in about 20 provinces over the weekend to call for fresh elections, a new Constitution and reforms of the monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Football’s Boo Birds Are All Cooped Up
description: N.F.L. fans in the Northeast, lusty booers in normal times, have had to watch their teams’ dim performances from afar, without recourse. “I have no way to release my venom,” one Jets fan said.
content: Drew Kanevsky, a Jets season-ticket holder since 2002, misses the familiar game day rhythms when the team is at home: putting on his trusty No. 74 Nick Mangold jersey, tailgating at Lot K1 at MetLife Stadium, explaining nuances to his 10-year-old son, Anthony, that the television feed doesn’t show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 6 of the N.F.L. Season
description: The Titans rumbled for 601 yards in an overtime win. The Steelers crushed the Browns, the Buccaneers upset the Packers and the lowly Giants finally gave New Jersey a win.
content: It was not the day many people expected. The Broncos, the Falcons and the Bears all pulled off upsets on the road. The Buccaneers made easy work of the Packers, the Eagles gave the Ravens a scare, and the Browns went from looking like an offensive juggernaut in Weeks 2 through 5 to being absolutely humiliated by the Steelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Weiyi Cai and Denise Lu
title: Flush With Cash, Biden Eclipses Trump in War for the Airwaves
description: Joe Biden is vastly outspending President Trump in TV advertising, maintaining a nearly 2-to-1 advantage on the airwaves.
content: Joe Biden is vastly outspending President Trump in TV advertising, maintaining a nearly 2-to-1 advantage on the airwaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kassie Bracken, Alexandra Eaton, Aaron Byrd, Brian Dawson, Ben Laffin, Caroline Kim and Kevin Oliver
title: This U.S. Election Could Be the Most Secure Yet. Here’s Why.
description: With early voting underway, states are working to reassure voters that their ballots will be counted as cast. Our video shows how states’ responses to Russian hacking and the coronavirus crisis have helped make the election more secure than ever.
content: With early voting underway, states are working to reassure voters that their ballots will be counted as cast. Our video shows how states’ responses to Russian hacking and the coronavirus crisis have helped make the election more secure than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Adriana Balsamo
title: Become a Dessert Person and Face the Haunts in Edith Wharton’s Home
description: Listen to the audio play ‘Shipwreck,’ bake some madeleines with Sur La Table and make dinosaur-shadow puppets.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Anne Washburn Just Wants Her Trump Play to Be Irrelevant
description: “Shipwreck,” a fantasia about white liberals and the president’s infamous dinner with James Comey, has been adapted into an audio play.
content: When Anne Washburn wrote her play “Shipwreck,” in a white-hot dash inspired by a single news cycle of the Trump era, she didn’t care whether it had a future.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amy Coney Barrett’s Belief in Originalism: Conservative or Radical?

title: Is Wishing Trump Ill a Moral Transgression?
